abstract.p: The inner canthal orbicularis drives spontaneous blinking of the eyelids and is richly innervated by a branching network of twigs based largely on the buccal branch of the facial nerve. This segment of the orbicularis is relatively resistant to denervation from subciliary incisional approaches. Combined with proper eyelid tension, contraction of this segment of orbicularis results in the normal physiologic blink mechanism. The authors discuss how to achieve proper eyelid tension and position intraoperatively during the treatment of patients with a range of orbital morphologies.

body.p: On occasion, a stimulus for inquiry does not originate completely from academic curiosity but as a reaction to theories proposed by others that seem faulty. Such was a response to a premise promoted several years ago by some in the plastic surgery community that was advanced in peer-reviewed plastic surgery journals and at national surgical meetings. The foundation of this premise was based on cadaveric studies that demonstrated that nerve branches to the pretarsal orbicularis can be transected during a routine subciliary lower lid blepharoplasty incision. This was used as an effort to explain the occurrence of postoperative lower lid malposition following lower lid blepharoplasty. The authors then postulated that the standard blepharoplasty subciliary incision through skin and muscle likely caused damage to the motor innervation of the orbicularis muscle, which would then cause clinical harm to the patient 1 ; the authors seemed to generalize their premise to include any surgery involving a subciliary incision. 2 Other studies and discussions followed, with similar conclusions based on further cadaveric dissections. 3,4

This notion was contrary to the experience of ophthalmologists and oculoplastic surgeons who had been performing lower lid surgery for many decades. A number of nationally and internationally respected oculoplastic surgeons were privately consulted for their opinions on this premise and their response was one of universal rejection, based on personal communications by letter between the senior author (CDM) and George Bartley, MD, John Shore, MD, FACS, Allen Putterman, MD, SC, Richard Lisman, MD, Richard Collin, MA FRCS, Franz Josef Steinkogler, MD, Mike Patipa, MD, FACS, and Richard Anderson, MD. The authors feel that this erroneous concept needs to be addressed because of its incorrectness and, more particularly, because it affected a subspecialty of surgeons who make lower lid incisions in the course of their normal surgical practice.

The occurrence of lower lid denervation caused as a result of subciliary incisions was rebutted with electromyographic (EMG) evidence: lower lid EMG results were found to be normal before and after subciliary incision combined with orbicularis dissection, as performed in cosmetic patients. 5 In addition, this disconnect between the plastic surgery literature and the opinions of numerous oculoplastic surgeons stimulated a review of our past clinical experience with orbicularis surgery and spurred further investigative efforts in our practice to clarify eyelid motor innervation and the mechanics of the orbicularis oculi muscle. The initial effort was a review of past surgical treatment of blepharospasm patients, in which the orbicularis muscle was selectively denervated and resected. The surgery cases for benign essential blepharospasm (BEB) were all completed in the years before botulinum toxin injections; however, all records, images, and videos of the blepharospasm patients had been retained and were used in this review.

sec.title: The Surgical Treatment of Blepharospasm Patients
sec.p: Historically, for those patients with BEB who were resistant to medical therapy, surgical intervention was performed in due course using 2 procedures. The initial procedure involved surgical denervation of the eyelids with the Reynolds technique. Subsequently, the surgical deconstruction of the eyelids was performed with a modification of Anderson’s neuromyectomy. 6 Later, botulinum toxin type A (Botox; Allergan, Inc, Irvine, California) replaced surgical treatment in most cases; however, valuable insight into the biomechanics of eyelid movement was gained with the surgical procedures described.

sec.title: Reynolds Procedure
sec.p: From 1975 to 1980, 22 patients (44 procedures) were treated by the senior author (C.D.M.) and his colleagues for BEB using the technique described by Reynolds et al, 7 with good improvement in most. 8 An incision was made into the parotid gland, and the trunks of the facial nerve were identified and stimulated to demonstrate which nerve fibers were causing spasms in the eyelids. Only those nerve branches that created eyelid spasms were avulsed, and only the zygomatic branches of the facial nerve were involved (Figure 1). All surgeries showed reduction or elimination of spasms with good retention of eyelid closure by blinking. No lower lid ectropion was observed in the majority of these patients (Figure 2A-C). An occasional patient did show some deficiency in blinking, as well as lower lid malposition. A close inspection of the postoperative images revealed that these patients also demonstrated ipsilateral weakness in lip elevation, demonstrating loss of buccal branch function. Since only the visible zygomatic branches were avulsed, it was felt that in these patients, the loss of buccal branch activity was the result of either anastomotic variation of nerve branching or surgical error (Figure 2D-F). This procedure alleviated many of the patients’ spasms and allowed them to become functional in most cases, although recurrence of spasms occurred in many patients over a period of time. Due to a high incidence of facial nerve regeneration and recurrence of spasms, surgeons treating blepharospasm began to employ the addition of orbicularis myectomy to the treatment regimen.

sec.title: Modified Anderson Procedure
sec.p: From 1980 to 1985, a variation of the Anderson myectomy 6 was performed by the senior author (C.D.M.) involving excision of the extracanthal orbicularis (pretarsal, preseptal, and orbital orbicularis), corrugator, and procerus muscles through an open coronal incision. 9 This also included excision of the peripheral motor nerves innervating the muscles (Figure 3). In all patients, the inner canthal orbicularis was left intact because of its observed lack of recruitment during provocative electrostimulation performed for the production of eyelid spasms (Figure 4). All patients treated with complete extracanthal orbicularis myectomy experienced elimination of spasm, maintenance of normal blink mechanism, and lack of lower lid malposition. Videos demonstrating this procedure are available at www.aestheticsurgeryjournal.com. You may also scan the code on the first page of this article with your smartphone to be taken directly to the video on www.YouTube.com.

Combined with proper eyelid tension, contraction of this segment of orbicularis results in the normal physiologic blink mechanism. In a series of 9 videos accompanying their Special Topic article, Dr McCord and his co-authors demonstrate how to achieve proper eyelid tension and position intraoperatively during the treatment of patients with a range of orbital morphologies.

sec.title: A Modified Functional Classification of the Orbicularis Oculi
sec.p: Observations from the surgical outcomes of the treatment of BEB with the myectomy procedure suggest a reclassification of the orbicularis muscle with regard to function. The previous description of the orbicularis muscle describes a distinction between the orbital, preseptal, and pretarsal portions of the orbicularis: the pretarsal portion subserves spontaneous blinking, the orbital portion subserves forced closure, and the preseptal portion performs a combination of each. 10 As a result of the findings of the above myectomy procedures, it became clear that normal blinking and normal lower lid position are retained even after all extracanthal orbicularis has been excised. Extracanthal excision did eliminate the offending eyelid spasms of BEB. This suggests a more precise division of labor that recognizes the distinction between inner canthal and extracanthal orbicularis in the eyelid closure mechanism. The extracanthal orbicularis, innervated by zygomatic branches of the facial nerve, is responsible for squeezing, animation, expression, and protection from flying objects and is the cause of most symptoms of BEB (Figure 5A). As we casually watch television, we do not use the extracanthal orbicularis or its zygomatic innervation. By contrast, the inner canthal orbicularis, currently appreciated to be innervated by the buccal branches of the facial nerve, is responsible for normal blinking, passive eyelid closure, lower lid tone and position, and the tear pump movements of the eyelids. The inner canthal orbicularis itself is substantial in size, significantly thicker than the pretarsal orbicularis, with thick extensions that insert deep in the medial canthus (Figure 5B). As we sit passively in a room blinking, only the inner canthal orbicularis is contracting.

caption.p: (A) Extracanthal orbicularis. The extracanthal orbicularis (shaded) is responsible for squeezing, animation, expression, and ocular protection form flying objects. This portion receives motor nerve supply from the zygomatic branch of the facial nerve. (B) Inner canthal orbicularis. Inner canthal orbicularis (shaded) is responsible for the maintenance of lower eyelid tone and position, blinking, and the tear pump. This portion receives motor nerve supply from the buccal branch of the facial nerve.

sec.title: Innervation
sec.p: The division in orbicularis function also dictates a concomitant division of innervation as well. In both the Reynolds procedure and the modified Anderson neuromyectomy, the zygomatic nerve supply to the orbicularis muscle was completely excised, leaving only the buccal branch for eyelid innervation. In 1985 (just before the advent of botulinum toxin injections), EMG studies were performed on the strips of orbicularis dissected with the neuromyectomy procedure that were still attached in the inner canthus. In these studies, the extracanthal orbicularis was completely dissected free, with the exception of its base, which was left intact at the inner canthus. The main trunk of the facial nerve was then stimulated and action potentials were observed in the orbicularis (Figure 6). These action potentials could only have originated from the intact buccal branch of the facial nerve (C. D. McCord and D. Gossman, unpublished data, 1985).

(B) Action potentials are recorded from the orbicularis pedicle originating at the inner canthus. A voltage probe is placed along the orbicularis pedicle. (C) Action potentials are recorded from the orbicularis pedicle originating at the inner canthus. An action potential is demonstrated in the orbicularis pedicle after facial nerve stimulation. sec.title: Buccal Branch
sec.p: With the findings above, the anatomic pathway and distribution of the buccal branch of the facial nerve assumes great importance in eyelid closure movements. A reduction or loss in blinking can be seen in the occasional patient with accidental injury of buccal branch twigs during surgery. This has occurred during external dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery (Figure 7A,B), Mohs surgical excision of medial canthal tumors (Figure 7C,D), and tear trough procedures. (A related video is available at www.aestheticsurgeryjournal.com.) Anatomic dissections of the buccal branch have been performed by Japanese ophthalmologists who, appropriately, were puzzled by the maintenance of normal spontaneous blinking after myectomy procedures in patients with BEB. 11 Their dissections demonstrated that the buccal branch passes through a triangular window formed by the inferior edge of the orbicularis muscle, the zygomaticus minor muscle, and the alaeque nasi muscle and then passes over (or under) the levator labii muscle, to a variable degree, and then proceeds to innervate the inner canthal orbicularis and portions of the corrugator and procerus muscles (Figure 8).

caption.p: (A) Selective injury of buccal branches during dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) occurs uncommonly and leads to paralytic lagophthalmos, which tends to resolve over months. Here, at postoperative week 1, a standard external DCR incision is noted in the territory of the buccal branch. (B). Impaired eyelid closure is demonstrated. (C) Selective injury of the buccal branches during Mohs resection of cutaneous malignancy. The surgical defect is in the territory of the buccal branches. (D) Paralytic lagophthalmos is demonstrated during the first postoperative visit. Reprinted with permission from McCord CD Jr, Codner MA. Eyelid & Periorbital Surgery. St Louis, MO: Quality Medical Publishing; 2008.

Nemoto’s triangle. The deep and superficial ramifications of the buccal branches are depicted relative to the levator labii. The triangle (dashed lines) through which these branches pass is delineated by the zygomaticus minor and levator alequae nasi. Reprinted with permission from McCord CD Jr, Codner MA. Eyelid & Periorbital Surgery. St Louis, MO: Quality Medical Publishing; 2008.

sec.p: Similar dissections were repeated in a study we performed on 6 cadavers, confirming the same pathways of the buccal branch of the facial nerve. In our dissections (Figure 9), the buccal branch more commonly traveled beneath the levator labii muscle. The dissection was difficult, and the nerve branches were smaller than expected. In all dissections, several branches appeared to anastamose with regional sensory nerves, including the infraorbital nerve primarily, as well as the supratrochlear and infratrochlear nerves (C. D. McCord and D. Ford, unpublished data, 2003-2004). A review of the literature supports this interpretation. 12,13 Motor nerve parasitization of sensory nerve trunks is well known and presumably serves to amplify the field of innervation of the motor nerve. Nerve specimens from our dissections, as well as from the dissections by others, 13 demonstrate nerve branches bundling 2 separate nerve trunks, presumably 1 motor bundle and 1 sensory bundle (to our knowledge, there is no readily available histological stain to distinguish motor from sensory nerves). This motor parasitization of sensory nerves along the same nerve tree suggests that the motor supply to the orbicularis might properly be considered to produce a “field” of innervation (Figure 10) that is more extensive than the macroscopic location of a single nerve. This thereby provides evidence that, in certain areas such as the orbicularis muscle, one cannot attribute the effect of a single motor nerve without considering the overall innervation of the effector organ, the orbicularis muscle.

(C) Top: Infraorbital nerve branches and buccal branches merge. The site of merger is biopsied. (D) Further relations between buccal branches and local sensory nerves. sec.title: Orbicularis Motor End Plates
sec.p: During a national plastic surgery meeting in 2005, an associate (Mark A. Codner, MD) found it necessary to refute a prominent plastic surgeon who dismissed the importance of the inner canthal orbicularis during eyelid blinking mechanics. In the dismissing surgeon’s view, the role of the inner canthal orbicularis was overstated because his own studies failed to identify significant motor end plates in histological preparations of that region of the orbicularis muscle (M. A. Codner, personal communication, 2005). In light of this statement, a study was undertaken, in conjunction with the Emory University Department of Cell Biology, which demonstrated that the orbicularis muscle was, in fact, replete with motor end plates. The motor end plates became evident after using a more specific motor end plate-specific stain, rhodamine-conjugated α-bungarotoxin (Figure 11). At the conclusion of the study, Dr Arthur English, the collaborating cell biologist, stated that the “orbicularis motor end plate arrangement is unlike any other skeletal muscle in the body, except cardiac muscle. The eyelid muscle acts as a functional syncytium. Action potentials fired from different neurons lead to a faster impulse transmission, which is needed for the function of the eyelid.” (H. Seify and A. English, unpublished data, 2005).

caption.p: (A) Cadaveric dissection of the orbicularis. Specimens were taken from the inner canthal orbicularis, as noted. Note the thickness of the inner canthal orbicularis, as compared with the extracanthal orbicularis. Double-fluorescent staining was performed for inner orbicularis motor end plates. (B) Cadaveric dissection of the orbicularis. Oil immersion view of fluorescein isothiocyanate-conjugated swine anti-rabbit secondary antibodies (green) binding to rabbit anti-human primary antibodies specific for motor end plates. Performed and interpreted, with great appreciation, by Dr Arthur English, Professor of Cell Biology, Emory University. (C) Cadaveric dissection of the orbicularis. Rhodamine-labeled α-bungarotoxin demonstrates numerous motor end plates (red). Performed and interpreted, with great appreciation, by Dr Arthur English, Professor of Cell Biology, Emory University. Reprinted with permission from McCord CD Jr, Codner MA. Eyelid & Periorbital Surgery. St Louis, MO: Quality Medical Publishing; 2008.

sec.p: Coupled with our observations after the surgical treatment of blepharospasm, the fact that orbicularis innervation resembles a functional syncytium further serves to weaken the premise that a single subciliary incision can have a damaging, denervating effect on the eyelid. Under the weight of the clinical evidence, we can assert rather strongly that the engine of lid position, tone, and spontaneous lid blinking is the inner canthal orbicularis, with its buccal branch innervation. As in all systems, without adequate resistance, an engine can do no meaningful work. A more complete understanding of eyelid configuration and closure mechanics requires an appreciation of the rest of the biomechanical system, specifically canthal anchoring and the surgical modifications thereof.

sec.title: Lateral Canthal Anchoring
sec.p: The tension achieved with lateral canthal anchoring procedures has long been known to provide support to the lower lid for the prevention of abnormal lower lid position and contour. 14 The quality of this fixation (position and tension) also affects the shape of the eye fissure and plays an important role in the mechanics of eyelid closure when blinking.

sec.title: Eye Fissure Shape and Lateral Canthal Anchoring
sec.p: Before discussing surgical decision making during lateral canthal anchoring, it is important to understand the perception of the “normal” eye fissure shape, particularly as perceived by patients before and after cosmetic surgery. Intraoperative decision making during lateral canthal fixation has a direct effect on that shape. Eye fissure shape is normally defined by the 2 white triangles on either side of the cornea, the nasal triangle and the lateral triangle (Figure 12). The nasal triangle has the least variability with surgery. It is the lateral scleral triangle that commonly varies in size and shape with the surgical positioning of the lateral canthus. Normally, the lateral scleral triangle is larger and more triangular than the nasal scleral triangle. In addition, the lateral canthus is usually positioned at a slightly higher level than the medial canthus. (The horizontal corneal diameter and corneal shape is roughly the same in all adults.)

caption.p: The eye fissure shape, as defined by the lateral and nasal scleral triangles. Reprinted with permission from McCord CD Jr, Codner MA. Eyelid & Periorbital Surgery. St Louis, MO: Quality Medical Publishing; 2008.

sec.p: Aside from the lateral canthal anchor point, lower eyelid contour and eye fissure shape are also a function of globe prominence. The interplay between the position and tone of the lateral canthus with the prominence of the eye, as measured by an exophthalmometer, was reflected by a study in which preoperative exophthalmometry was correlated with intraoperative canthal anchoring adjustments needed to produce the desired eye fissure shape end point. 15 In eyes with “standard” prominence (15-18 mm), the proper shape is obtained by positioning the lateral canthal anchoring point level with the inferior edge of the standard pupil (3-4 mm diameter intraoperatively), the “standard” anchor point (Figure 13).

caption.p: “Standard” eye prominence. The lateral canthus is anchored at the inferior border of the pupil to achieve a normal eye fissure shape. Reprinted with permission from McCord CD Jr, Codner MA. Eyelid & Periorbital Surgery. St Louis, MO: Quality Medical Publishing; 2008.

sec.p: In “deep-set” eyes (less than 15 mm), anchoring performed at the “standard” anchor point (or higher) results in upward clotheslining, with reduction and narrowing of the lateral scleral triangle (Figure 14). These patients complain of a “squinty” eye (Figure 15). In this “deep-set” patient population, eye fissure shape is normalized by placing the canthal anchor point further downward and inward.

caption.p: The “deep-set” eye. Anchoring at the “standard” anchor point tends to cause upward clotheslining of the lower eyelid, creating a small-eyed “squinty” look. To achieve the proper eye tissue shape, the anchor point needs to be infraplaced and positioned more posteriorly. Reprinted with permission from McCord CD Jr, Codner MA. Eyelid & Periorbital Surgery. St Louis, MO: Quality Medical Publishing; 2008.

Surgical repositioning of the lateral canthi in a patient with “deep-set” eyes. (A) Preoperative photo demonstrates small, rounded eye fissures after inappropriate canthal positioning. (B) Postoperative photo demonstrates wider-appearing eyes with increased lateral scleral triangles after drill-hole canthal fixation in a more inferior and posterior location. Reprinted with permission from McCord CD Jr, Codner MA. Eyelid & Periorbital Surgery. St Louis, MO: Quality Medical Publishing; 2008.

sec.p: In “prominent” eyes (greater than 18 mm), anchoring performed at the “standard” anchor point results in downward clotheslining and inferior scleral show (Figure 16). Supraplacement of canthal anchoring, many times combined with release of the inferior retinaculum, can reposition the lower lid in cases of mild prominence. However, excessive supraplacement of the lateral canthus, with concomitant supraplacement of the upper crus of the lateral canthal tendon, weakens upper lid closure and results in lagophthalmos (Figure 17; a related video is available at www.aestheticsurgeryjournal.com). Because of this phenomenon, the practical limitation of lateral canthal supraplacement in prominent eyes is typically at the level of the superior border of the standard pupil (Figure 18). Supplemental lower lid elevating procedures such as release of the inferior retractors or spacer insertion should be used in these situations to avoid impairing upper lid closure. In some cases involving more prominent eyes, in an effort to avoid pathologic supraplacement of the upper lid lateral canthal tendon, a “crisscross fixation” technique that separately fixates the upper and lower crura can be used 16,17 (Figure 19; a related video is available at www.aestheticsurgeryjournal.com).

caption.p: The “prominent” eye. Anchoring at the “standard” anchor point often causes inferior scleral show. The correct canthal position is more superior. Reprinted with permission from McCord CD Jr, Codner MA. Eyelid & Periorbital Surgery. St Louis, MO: Quality Medical Publishing; 2008.

(A) This 54-year-old man has lateral canthi positioned at the superior border of the pupil, which is too high for this patient’s orbital configuration. (B) Attempted closure demonstrates that the tissue bunches up laterally and there is lagophthalmos. (C) Chin-up positioning demonstrates the lagophthalmos more clearly. A prominent band of exposure keratopathy was present at the slit lamp. (D) At 1 month postoperatively, drill-hole canthal fixation and lower eyelid spacer placement demonstrate infraplacement of the canthi. The effect of lateral canthal supraplacement on eyelid closure. Excessive lateral canthal supraplacement clearly impairs upper eyelid blink and closure, the exact mechanism of which remains uncertain. Possible etiologies include a decrease in upper eyelid tension (due to “splinting” of the lateral aspect of the upper eyelid with the supraplaced lower lid) or a purely mechanical impediment to closure as the upper crus of the lateral canthal tendon interacts more intimately with the lower eyelid tarsus. sec.title: Canthal Fixation and Eyelid Closure Biomechanics
sec.p: As previously mentioned, a normal blink involves the contracture of the inner canthal orbicularis muscles. When unopposed, this activity will tend to pull the eyelids toward the nose. A counterpull at the lateral canthus must be present to convert the inner canthal pull to a vertical vector so that the eyelids will close with each blink. If this counterpull is lost due to canthal weakness or dehiscence (the “free-floating” canthus), the vertical vector of closure will be lost. Impaired blink excursion and blink velocity will result, leading to inadequate eyelid closure, producing a characteristic “fishmouthing” movement of the lids toward the nose during blinks (Figure 20; a related video is available at www.aestheticsurgeryjournal.com).

caption.p: “Fishmouthing” eyelid movements during blink. Top: Intact canthal fixation allows the conversion of orbicularis contraction into brisk vertical eyelid closure during a normal blink. Bottom: Lateral canthal dehiscence produces a characteristic “fishmouthing” movement during attempted closure, leading to incomplete blink and in many cases ocular surface consequences. Reproduced from information provided in McCord CD Jr, Codner MA. Eyelid & Periorbital Surgery. St Louis, MO: Quality Medical Publishing; 2008.

sec.p: Inadequacy or dehiscence of the lateral canthus can occur from the aging process (the cumulative effect on the canthal tendon from decades of 10-12 blinks per minute), inflammation, and trauma (including surgical trauma). In clinical situations where there is canthal dehiscence causing poor closure (and often anomalous eye fissure shape), reattachment of the canthal tendons with standard canthoplasty techniques can be performed when the quality of the tissue permits. With inadequacies in the eyelid tissue or periosteum, advanced techniques such as drill-hole fixation or special patching with fascia or acellular porcine cross-linked dermal collagen (ENDURAGen; Stryker, Inc, Kalamazoo, Michigan) may be used. 16,17

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This review of the biomechanics of eyelid closure and position incorporated decades of oculoplastic surgical experience, anatomical studies, and histological studies to develop a reclassification of the division of labor of the orbicularis oculi muscle, emphasizing the central importance of the inner canthal orbicularis and its buccal branch innervation, as well as its role in spontaneous blinking. Its role in supporting lower eyelid position and lower eyelid tone also continues to be significant. The presence or absence of isolated lower eyelid subciliary incisions plays no role in this model. Specific considerations should be made for canthal anchoring to ensure a desired eye fissure shape.
